title: Trump says he will try to get back territory for Ukraine in talks with Putin
summary:
Trump says he will try to get back territory for Ukraine in talks with Putin1 day ago Share Save Rachel Hagan & Laura Gozzi BBC News Share SaveWatch: 'We're going to change the battle lines' Trump on the war in UkraineUS President Donald Trump has said he will try to get some territory back for Ukraine during his meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday.
We're going to try to get some of that territory back for Ukraine," he told a news conference at the White House.
Trump claimed that he could know within two minutes of meeting Putin whether progress was possible.
Trump said he will update European leaders if Putin proposes a "fair deal" during the talks, adding that he would speak to Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky first "out of respect".
Trump has previously blamed Zelensky for the war in Ukraine, which was sparked by Russia's full-scale invasion of the country in February 2022.

title: Patriot missile production is surging, but the demand is insatiable
summary:
US Army EuropeAmerican defense companies are cranking out Patriot interceptors at a record-breaking pace, but demand is surging.
Amid global conflicts and growing worries in the West about a major conflict against a peer-level adversary, air defense missiles are in huge demand.
Meanwhile, Boeing is surging PAC-3 missile seekers, critical components that enable the Patriot system to identify, track, and intercept threats, and Raytheon, which makes Patriot radars and launchers, is boosting PAC-2 interceptor missile production.
A Patriot Air and Missile Defense launcher fires an interceptor.
RaytheonHoffman cautioned that even if the West's production of missile interceptors, like the Patriots, exceeds Russian conventional ballistic missile production, "this will not solve Europe's problems."

title: Nvidia’s Six-Word Response to China
summary:
“Embedding backdoors and kill switches into chips would be a gift to hackers and hostile actors,” the company wrote.
The Deal That Sparked the FireThis new firestorm in Beijing was ignited by the unconventional deal Nvidia just struck with Washington.
To return to China after months of a federal ban, the company agreed to pay the Trump administration 15% of the revenue generated by its H2O chip sales there.
Trump then dismissed the H2O chips as “obsolete” and “an old chip that China already has.”The president’s comments perfectly capture the absurd tightrope Nvidia is now forced to walk.
The U.S. President is calling it old news, while Chinese state media is calling it a security risk.

title: ‘Weapons’ Runs to Big $70M Global Opening in Debut Weekend
summary:
And the answer to that question is a resounding “yes.”Per Variety, Zach Cregger’s sophomore outing earned $70 million worldwide.
For the family-focused crowd—well, the other part of that crowd, since Weapons is about missing kids—Freakier Friday also did pretty well.
Disney’s legacy sequel starring Lindsay Lohan and Jamie Lee Curtis made $44.5 million worldwide, led largely by its domestic take of $29 million.
And Superman continues to hold strong with $578.8 million worldwide.
After becoming the highest-grossing domestic Superman movie last week, it’s poised to make (or exceed) $600 million worldwide before it hits streaming on August 26.

title: Prominent Chinese diplomat Liu Jianchao taken for questioning, sources say
summary:
BEIJING (Reuters) -Senior Chinese diplomat Liu Jianchao, widely seen as a potential foreign minister, was taken away by authorities for questioning in early August, five people familiar with the matter said.
Advertisement AdvertisementAdvertisement Advertisement"It removes a frontrunner to succeed Wang Yi and deprives China of a potential next steward for China's foreign policy."
Another diplomat who met his aides around that time said they were very confident that he would soon be promoted to foreign minister.
Unusually for a Chinese diplomat, he served two successive postings in China's anti-corruption bureaucracy between 2015 and 2018, when he helped track down corrupt officials who fled overseas.
A person familiar with China's foreign ministry said that Liu was liked and well-respected by Chinese diplomats for his outstanding ability and warm, friendly demeanour.

title: Chinese ships slam into one another during a South China Sea chase, Philippine Coast Guard video shows
summary:
A Chinese navy warship and a China Coast Guard cutter crashed into one another in the South China Sea on Monday while chasing a Philippine Coast Guard vessel, video footage shows.
As it closed in on the Philippine vessel, the Chinese coast guard ship suddenly slammed into a larger Chinese Navy destroyer that unexpectedly passed between the Philippine vessel and the Chinese cutter.
Here is a longer video capturing the collision between the PLA Navy 164 and the China Coast Guard 3104.
The collision came amid the latest in a long list of confrontations between China and the Philippines in the South China Sea.
The Philippines has accused Chinese Coast Guard vessels of engaging in dangerous and provocative maneuvers with its ships in the past.

title: Nvidia Just Dodged an $8 Billion Bullet, Thanks to Donald Trump
summary:
According to the Financial Times, the breakthrough came after Huang’s visit to the White House on August 6 to meet with President Donald Trump.
To prevent this, the U.S. has imposed strict export controls, blocking the sale of top-tier AI chips to China.
The Power of Personal DiplomacyReversing this policy took months of intense diplomacy and lobbying, culminating in Huang’s personal visits to the White House.
During a White House AI summit last month, Trump admitted he had initially considered taking antitrust action against the chip giant before he got to know its CEO.
With the $8 billion revenue threat now averted and the $50 billion China market reopened, investors will be watching closely when Nvidia reports its quarterly earnings later this month.

title: US demands cut of Nvidia sales in order to ship AI chips to China
summary:
is a news writer who covers the streaming wars, consumer tech, crypto, social media, and much more.
The Trump administration has ordered Nvidia and AMD to pay the federal government a 15 percent cut of their AI chip sales revenue to China, according to reports from The New York Times and The Financial Times.
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang reportedly reached an agreement with President Donald Trump just days before the Commerce Department granted the companies licenses to sell AI chips.
“I said, ‘Listen, I want 20 percent if I’m going to approve this for you, for the country,’” Trump said.
After the Trump administration put restrictions on AI chip sales to China in April, both companies confirmed last month that they would soon resume shipments once they received licenses.
